bioghist.p: Dorothy McCauley, long-time resident of Detroit, Michigan, was organizer and executive director of the Dav-Joy-Lin-Dex Community Council, an association of businesses, church and school leaders, and block clubs in the area bounded by Davison, Joy, Linwood, and Dexter in northwest Detroit. Founded in 1961, the Dav-Joy-Lin-Dex Community Council is a "non-partisan, civic organization dedicated to maintaining, improving and developing the area as a better place to live." The Council has involved itself with youth, senior citizen, recreation, health, welfare, education, and other local and civic programs. The Council has been especially concerned with matters of home improvement and neighborhood development. With money received from the city of Detroit's Neighborhood Opportunity Fund, McCauley as head of the Council's Non-Profit Housing Corporation worked to coordinate the screening and contracting of senior citizen home repairs. McCauley was ever vigilant about the kinds of businesses wanting to operate in her neighborhood, using the influence of the Council to circulate petitions addressed to Detroit Common Council urging them to deny requests of individuals wanting to establish arcades, a methadone treatment center, and other "seedy, slum-inducing businesses" that had been uprooted from the city's downtown because of urban renewal.

scopecontent.p: The McCauley collection consists of the records of the Dav-Joy-Lin-Dex Community Council but including as well files documenting McCauley's other community activities. Of most importance in understanding the work of the Council are its News Bulletins which date from 1960 to 1989. In addition to neighborhood news, the bulletins included notes about city government, particularly as they related to this local neighborhood. The News Bulletins were also the place where McCauley informed the community about the Council's various petition drives.

As executive secretary of the Council, McCauley wanted her group to act as a clearinghouse of information about matters of neighborhood concern. Her collection reflects this interest. Besides material about the Council, McCauley also preserved records about the various block clubs that made up the Council. The great bulk of these relate to the Dexter-Elmhurst Advisory Board, but there are also newsletters for the Glynn Court Block Club and the Calvert Civic Block Club.
